utterances: Given the fact that Barack Obama is only about 78 pounds and nobody will dare ask Hillary Clinton what her weight is, so I think it's going to be a key issue in 2008 without a doubt.
This premise may be thin, but I'm going to make some of my own big prognostications.
John Edwards: he looks to me like he's got a little too much junk in the trunk.
Though no one will cite this as the reason, his candidacy will sink.
(Soundbite of music)
Mike Huckabee: Sure, he recently lost 110 pounds - the equivalent of a whole person - but he'd have to gain a person in order to win.
A person with some name recognition.
(Soundbite of music)
Barack Obama: I am certainly not the first to note that with so few years of experience, he needs to add some heft to his campaign, but I mean that literally.
Hillary Clinton: Let's just say that between some of her vague sounding talking points and those boxy suits, I'd advise streamlining on all fronts.
And sides.
Joe Biden: Bad hair transplant, foot in the mouth, weight is a non-issue.
Do we really want a president named Mitt?
John McCain and Rudy Giuliani: according to Newsday, they are buddies who often hold court over plates of pasta during Manhattan Chat'n'Chew.
My prediction: Those chat and chews will soon consist of cottage cheese and dry Melba toast.
It might be wise to remember the aphorism you can never be too rich or too thin.
So candidates, time to get serious about the campaign, and may the best candidate lose.
Annabelle Gurwitch - her documentary film ""Fired"" premiers next month on Showtime.

When the federal base-closing commission recommended shutting down Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, DC, word spread quickly among the hospital's neighbors, most of whom are African-American.
The institution has represented stability, protection and jobs for those who live nearby.
Many of them are now hoping Congress and the president might reverse the commission's ruling.
Nancy Marshall-Genzer reports.
The Base Closure and Realignment Commission says Walter Reed should be replaced with an expanded facility at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Maryland.
Geographically and culturally, that's a world away from Walter Reed's current home.
(Soundbite of traffic)
The hospital sits on Georgia Avenue, a busy north-south artery running through Washington.
There are row houses across the street with front porches made for passing time with the neighbors.
The Walter Reed Apartments are just down the street.
That's where 73-year-old Rosie Brown has lived for more than 20 years.
Some wounded veterans and their families are staying at the apartment complex.
Brown says she and her neighbors look after them.
If they're going up the street to the store at night, we make sure that they are safe, and they're just like our little kids.
They call me mama.
I'll be walking down the street last week, a car full of white kids passed, say, `Hi, Grandmom.
I say, `Hey, baby.
They say, `Who is that?
I say, `I don't know.'
Brown wonders who would look after her soldiers if Walter Reed were moved to Bethesda.
Workers at the hospital worry about how they'd commute to the Maryland suburbs.
Merrill Pickney(ph) has worked as a housekeeper at Walter Reed for 10 years.
He says he may quit rather than follow his job to Bethesda.
Well, there's nothing that I can do or I guess nobody else can do now because they've already made their decision to close.
I have to really think about it.
I'm not sure right now, but I am planning on retiring in the next few years.
So hopefully it'll still be open by the time I put in my papers and everything.
Congratulations Bryan on being one of the lucky millions to receive the email.
Thanks for calling.
Some critics suggest the administration doesn't have the political will to do that because allowing such a large refugee resettlement could look like an admission of failure in Iraq.
The State Department's Ellen Sauerbrey disagrees.
She says that humanitarian decisions are based on need.
Still, don't expect to see large numbers of Iraqi refugees in the U.S.
anytime soon.
It will probably be the next fiscal year before we would be able to have identified the needs and begun setting up a processing program and get people actually into the pipeline.
The World Series opens tonight in Chicago with the White Sox facing off against the Houston Astros.
NPR's Tom Goldman is covering the series.
We found him just before the game at US Cellular Field on his Verizon phone.
Hi, Tom.
Hi, Debbie.
You found me out.
Let's not talk about Verizon anymore, OK?
OK.
So after last year's thrilling victory by the Boston Red Sox, we've got another hard-luck team in this one: the White Sox.
But this isn't quite like last year, is it?
It's not and, you know, you could argue that nothing will match last year with the Red Sox ending their curse and their anguish.
And actually, got a couple of good teams.
I mean, it--you know, they have got some histories of their own.
Let's talk a little bit more about the Astros and the White Sox.
The fans have to be very excited about this since it's something very new for both of these cities to be in the World Series.
Extremely excited--at least half of Chicago, because the other half loves the Chicago Cubs--is thrilled.
This team has not been to the World Series since 1959.
It has not won the World Series since 1917, and that's actually one year before the last time the Red Sox had won it before they won last year.
So they definitely have some history there.
The Houston Astros simply have never been here.
They've never been to a World Series in their 44-year history.
After such a long drought for both of these teams, what did they do to get here?
Well, what they did--I mean, Houston was close last year and the White Sox certainly were a good team, too.
What they're doing better than anyone else is pitching.
And that's really the story going into this--at least this first game of the World Series.
In the American League Championship Series against the LA Angels, the White Sox had four different pitchers pitch an entire game.
That means to the last out; no relief pitchers.
And Debbie, that is rare in this era of specialization.
As good as the White Sox pitchers are, Houston's pitching staff may even be better.
They've got more dominant pitchers in Andy Pettitte and Roger Clemens and Roy Oswalt.
The thing that's going to determine who wins this World Series is the batting.
Because, obviously, you've got to get runs and who--which team is going to break through against the other's outstanding pitching staff?
Both of these teams play what the so-called experts like to call `smart ball.
And that means they get little hits.
They bunt the ball.
They sacrifice players around the bases.
They move players around and advance them, so they kind of nickel and dime the other team and score runs that way.
It's kind of a scrappy approach.
Briefly, Tom, off the field, the start of this World Series was supposed to be a new step in baseball's battle against steroids.
Is that the case?
It was before Congress recently--the head of the union, Donald Fehr, said that we might have a new tougher steroid policy by the start of the World Series.
Well, tonight is the start of the World Series and lo and behold, we don't have it.
So that's not going to be news to a lot of critics who say that baseball has continuously dragged its feet on this issue.
I think baseball would like to get to the World Series, have everyone forget about the whole steroid issue by just watching some great baseball.
NPR's Tom Goldman in Chicago.
Thanks so much.
You're welcome, Debbie.
Back during the primary season, NPR's Linda Wertheimer paid a visit to Bloomer, Wisconsin, to talk to voters.
Bloomer's about 90 miles northeast of St. Paul.
Linda went back there this morning.
She stopped at the Main Street Cafe, a good place for a piece of pie and a range of political opinions.
especially opinions about the newest edition to the contest, Sarah Palin.
The earliest arrivals at the Main Street Cafe are the women who work in the pie kitchen, turning out hundreds of pies a day to be shipped around Wisconsin.
Ms.
JENNY REISHEL(ph) (Pie Baker): We've got two restaurants we've got to make pies for.
(Unintelligible) lemon meringue, strawberry rhubarb, sour cream raisin custard, Dutch and caramel apple.
Sounds good, doesn't it?
That's Jenny Reishel, one of the bakers in the special pie kitchen at the back of the Main Street Cafe.
Sarah Palin has not made an impression on Jenny.
She's still sorry Hillary Clinton isn't running.
I think if Clinton would've got it, she would've been my vote.
Her being a woman and her ideas, I think she would have done very well.
Jenny Reishel gets up way too early to listen to convention speeches.
Out in the cafe, the regulars begin to arrive along with the sunrise, including the ever-shifting group of euchre players in a corner booth.
Unidentified Man #1: I'm going go to pass.
Unidentified Man #2: I'm going to pick it up.
Kevin Harings(ph) played a few hands of euchre this morning and then told us that Sarah Palin pulled him back from a vote for the Democrats.
She changed his attitude toward John McCain.

As soon as I found that he was - who he picked for his running mate, I said, okay, I see - I thought he was just forward and set in his ways, but because he picked a woman, I thought he's going to have a good chance of winning now.
So Sarah Palin does make a difference in your vote?
Oh yeah, you know, because it showed his other side, that he's open-minded.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That's a bummer.
Alfa McPherson(ph) has lived across from Walter Reed for 37 years.
He's a retired Navy radio man.
He crosses the street to the hospital three times a month for his diabetes treatment.
These days he passes the occasional anti-war demonstrators at the hospital's gates, but in the 1970s, McPherson says the hospital workers protested.
They accused Walter Reed of discriminating against African-American employees who weren't getting promotions.
McPherson says he sees echoes of the past in the relocation proposal.
But you still wonder if it's still racially motivated because this is a major employer for the District of Columbia.
A lot of District residents have worked there.
Now their jobs are being moved.

And you have single parents who have baby-sitters and things that they have to deal with and being able to take transportation from where they live in the city to this hospital, since it's still within the boundaries of this city, it's a different thing than having to cross into Maryland.
McPherson worries that the market may determine what becomes of the Walter Reed property.
He speculates that once the hospital's multiethnic work force leaves, developers responding to strong demand for housing could turn it into a mostly white gated community.
The federal government hasn't revealed plans for the site if, as expected, President Bush and Congress agree with the recommendation to close Walter Reed.
